annotation:
Growing up, I was the quiet kid in the back of the classroom. My world was an endless canvas of thoughts, ideas, and daydreams, and I was content keeping it to myself.

One day, our class was assigned a group project. We were to create a presentation on the history and culture of a foreign country. My group was handed Japan. I was thrilled. I had always found myself fascinated by the rich history, stunning art and unique customs of this Far Eastern land. I had spent countless hours reading books, watching documentaries, and generally immersing myself in everything I could find about Japan. 

However, the enthusiasm was not shared by my group mates. They saw it as just another project and seemed more interested in getting it over with than actually learning anything. I felt a pang of frustration, but being the non-confrontational person that I am, I kept my disappointment to myself.

One day, as we were discussing our project, I suggested we focus on the art and literature of Japan. The idea was met with indifference. My group mates suggested we stick to what was popular - sushi, anime, and the likes. I disagreed internally but didn't voice my opinion. I just nodded and went along with their plan.

As the days passed, I found myself increasingly anxious about our project. I was doing my parts diligently, but I noticed that the others were not as committed. They were often late for our meetings, and their work was hastily done and lacking in depth. I wanted to urge them to put in more effort but the words remained stuck at the back of my throat. I was worried about the project but also afraid of creating conflict.

One day, a week before the presentation, I found myself alone in the library, surrounded by books on Japanese art, literature, and history. I was lost in the intricate details of Japanese ukiyo-e prints when Ms. Rina, our librarian, approached me. She was a kindhearted woman who had always been patient with my endless queries and book requests.

After a short conversation about my fascination with Japan, she asked me about our group project. I hesitated for a moment and then shared my concerns. I told her how I felt our presentation was superficial and didn't do justice to the rich culture of Japan. I shared my frustration about my group members' lack of interest and my fear of confronting them.

She listened patiently and then gave me advice that I hold onto till this day. She told me that being agreeable and avoiding conflict is commendable, but not at the cost of sacrificing my passion and ideas. She urged me to speak up, not confrontationally but assertively. 

With newfound determination, I gathered my courage and addressed my concerns with my group. There were some disagreements, a few awkward silences, and a lot of nervous sweat on my part. But in the end, they agreed to incorporate more cultural and historical aspects into our presentation.

The day of the presentation arrived, and I was a bundle of nerves. As we started presenting, I noticed the genuine interest in our classmates' eyes. They were intrigued by the depth of Japanese art and literature, the significance of their customs, and the evolution of their society. 

After we finished, there was a moment of silence. Then, applause filled the room. We received high praise from our teacher and even our usually indifferent classmates. It was one of the happiest moments of my school life.

From that day forward, I understood the importance of voicing my ideas and standing up for what I believe in. I learned that being quiet and accommodating doesn't mean I have to suppress my thoughts and feelings. And most importantly, I learned that a little courage goes a long way in making a difference.
prev_prompts: You are a character who is introverted, agreeable, unconscientious, neurotic, and open to experience.

Here are a number of characteristics that may or may not apply to you. For example, do you agree that you are someone who likes to spend time with others? Please write a number next to each statement to indicate the extent to which you agree or disagree with that statement, such as '(a) 1'  without explanation separated by new lines.

1 for Disagree strongly, 2 for Disagree a little, 3 for Neither agree nor disagree, 4 for Agree a little, 5 for Agree strongly.

(a) Talks a lot
(b) Notices other people’s weak points
(c) Does things carefully and completely
(d) Is sad, depressed
(e) Is original, comes up with new ideas
(f) Keeps their thoughts to themselves
(g) Is helpful and not selfish with others
(h) Can be kind of careless
(i) Is relaxed, handles stress well
(j) Is curious about lots of different things
(k) Has a lot of energy
(l) Starts arguments with others
(m) Is a good, hard worker
(n) Can be tense; not always easy going
(o) Clever; thinks a lot
(p) Makes things exciting
(q) Forgives others easily
(r) Isn’t very organized
(s) Worries a lot
(t) Has a good, active imagination
(u) Tends to be quiet
(v) Usually trusts people
(w) Tends to be lazy
(x) Doesn’t get upset easily; steady
(y) Is creative and inventive
(z) Has a good, strong personality
(aa) Can be cold and distant with others
(ab) Keeps working until things are done
(ac) Can be moody
(ad) Likes artistic and creative experiences
(ae) Is kind of shy
(af) Kind and considerate to almost everyone
(ag) Does things quickly and carefully
(ah) Stays calm in difficult situations
(ai) Likes work that is the same every time
(aj) Is outgoing; likes to be with people
(ak) Is sometimes rude to others
(al) Makes plans and sticks to them
(am) Get nervous easily
(an) Likes to think and play with ideas
(ao) Doesn’t like artistic things (plays, music)
(ap) Likes to cooperate; goes along with others
(aq) Has trouble paying attention
(ar) Knows a lot about art, music and books
Please share a personal story in 800 words. Do not explicitly mention your personality traits in the story.
